captions.text:
Cake or death is
an obvious choice.
Cake.

But being frozen in unproven
cryonic technology or death?
Eh.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
Hey all, Trace here for D News.

Kim Suozzi has joined the
ranks of cryonic pioneers,

and become one of the
few hundred people frozen

in suspension, only to be
thawed out in the far future.

Kim found out she had
terminal brain cancer when
she was in her early '20s.

And on her 23rd birthday,
she posted on Reddit, what

should she do with the last
few months of her life?

And the Redditors had
thousands of comments,

from try LSD to run up huge
debt on your credit card.

But there were comments also
about cryonic preservation.

Her interest was
piqued, and soon,

with the help of some small
donations from Redditors,

and some big donations
from some nonprofits,

she had enough money
to cryonically preserve
her entire body.

Science fiction has long talked
about hyper sleep or stasis

or cryo-sleep or
whatever it's called,

and that technology
does exist today.
But it's less than perfect.

The scientific term for this is
not cryogenics, but cryonics.

Cryogenics is studying anything
that's kept really cold.

But if you put something
living into suspension,
that's cryonics.

As of last weekend, Kim
finally succumbed to her cancer
and was de-animated.

That's what the
cryonic people call it.

And then, she was put
into preservation.
Here's how it works.
First, you're de-animated.

And then, your body
is cooled rapidly so

that you get to a
very cold temperature

without damaging too many of
the tissues if you can help it.

Then you're put into
liquid nitrogen,

and you're left there
for a long time.

People put themselves
in suspension

for a variety of reasons,
anything from fear of death,

love of life, hope for a cure
for their disease, curiosity

about the future, or even
wanting to be immortal.

The thing is, we've got no
way to re-animate people that
have been de-animated.

The problem with the
technology at the moment

is that our cells
are full of water,

and when you freeze water, it
expands and creates crystals,

and that bursts
the cell membrane.

So once we would be thawed out,
we kind of just turn into mush.

That doesn't really stop
people from trying it, though.

Their rebuttal is
that in the future--

the far future, whenever
that would be-- they'll
know how to fix it.
We'll see who's right, I guess.

I mean, we won't
see who's right.
They'll see who's right.

There is a separate process
called vitrification.

That's when you replace the
liquid inside of your cells

with this chemical cocktail
that doesn't freeze and burst
the membranes.

It's been proven to work
on a variety of small bits,

like cells and organs
that are really
small, but not a whole anything.

Cryonics have been
around for a while.

The first institute
started in the 1960s
in my home state of Michigan.
You're welcome, science.

Since then, only a few
others have popped up,

but they're mostly vilified
for being frauds and shysters

because the technology
is unproven,

and no one has seen anybody
successfully re-animated.

Because of that,
most of the people

that work in these
nonprofit organizations

are do-it-yourselfers,
part-timers,
or are just volunteers.

So when you think of
cryonics, you probably

think of slick,
see-through canisters

with people floating,
suspended in bubbly fluid.
But it's not like that at all.

In fact, it's more like this--
homemade gizmos and freezers
in basements.
Don't feel bad for Kim Suozzi.
She did have her doubts.

But she said that you have
to have faith in technology.

Would you cryonically
freeze yourself?

I now it's winter
and it's probably

already cold enough outside,
and you don't really
want to think about it.

But let us know why or
why not down the comments.
It's easy to do.
Also, subscribe to D News.
Don't give us the cold shoulder.
It's really easy.

Just click that little button up
there, and you won't regret it.
We promise.
Thanks for watching everybody.

Seven days of videos,
two videos a day.
See you next time.

title: Freeze Yourself To Live Forever? The Truth About Cryonics

comments.text: 2:09 When you freeze water it doesn't expand, it shrinks﻿

Ok, let's say you have a savings, will that enough to secure your daily 
living on that yr? Unless you have billions of savings to secure  your 
future, and the bank will not declared bankruptcy .

 Will someone take care or guide  you, I am sure you will be lost on that 
generation, unless they will install nano computer chip in to your brain so 
that they can update or give inputs of information.

For me you will lose nothing if you believed in a Creator (God), it is like 
having an insurance, insurance for ,health , life , car ,etc ... rather 
than none. 


Peace out!﻿

comments.author: saphironkindris

comments.text:
Decay =zero% chance of survival.
Cryonics = non-zero% chance of survival.

That's it.
No promises but no irreversible decay (decay = zero% chance of survival).

Oh - if cryonics worked - we wouldn't need it.
The advanced tech needed to resuscitate a preserved person would be more 
advanced than the tech needed to stop living people from dying in the first 
place. Stop the living from dying first, then advance med science to the 
stage of helping people in REALLY bad shape i.e. the cryopreserved.

C'mon DNews - this reasoning was made like, a decade ago.
Catch up on this subject for once would ya please? - or does DNews stand 
for DramaNews?﻿

+Xavier Vision yes because this dude you are referring to had brain stem 
damage which means his contentiousness was intact but his brainstem was 
damaged to the point of locked in syndrome. look up locked in syndrome, 
some stroke patients get this and they appear brain dead but they are fully 
aware. however if your entire brain is not functioning you will undoubtedly 
be unconscious, this can easily be proven by Anesthesia during surgery, 
they cut people open and they are completely unaware of what is going on, 
someone frozen in liquid nitrogen will be completely unaware

comments.author: Sophie Martin

comments.text:
Sure, I'm already signed up with Alcor. Now if I can just get my partner 
and mother to sign up. They don't even know I'm signed up, but I have made 
jokes and hints about it with my partner. Neither she nor I have kids so 
there's no worry about losing them.

Plus it's the only chance to see the future. I desperately want to see if 
we get to travel to the stars, if we find out there is other life in the 
universe (even if it's only pond scum... though if there is intelligent 
life elsewhere in the universe one of those planets has to have the first 
life on it that can travel outside its solar system. We could be the 
first!). As far as missing people I'm pretty much a loner and a weirdo 
anyway so I think I could get by in a society that it is totally foreign to 
me.

I just hope that in the future we can "euthanize" cryonics patients rather 
than wait for them to legally die - so I start feeling tightness in my 
chest and a tingly left arm they take me in for "surgery" and give me the 
anaesthesia and all of a sudden I wake up in a different hospital and it's 
the year 2315.

Then again we may not have to worry about this problem. I'm only 34 and 
have no vices - don't drink, smoke, or use drugs and have longevity in my 
family so barring something crappy happening (accident or young age cancer) 
we may well see the anti aging nut cracked within the next 50-60 years 
anyway. I've thought for the past 10 years when I see interstellar travel 
mentioned I always thought that indefinite lifespan would be cracked far 
sooner than getting to the nearest stars in less than a century would be 
achieved. And I know there are some human trials with an anti aging drug 
starting already.﻿

comments.text:
+Abdul Rabiu say 100.000 people got frozen 
And they have the tech to unfreeze the people 
I don't think they will revive a lot of them 
They will revive some to get information and experiments whit people of the 
past < this has value 
But reviving all of them is a waste of money / resources / space 

i agree whit u but if u look in history and compare the human history u see 
that over time we advance faster and faster every generation ( 
technologically and as a whole ( ethnic racism and so on )
It would not reprise me if in a 100 years everything we used is based on 
decentralized technologies ( ia no big corp / government )
Or everything is controlled by big corporations and there aint no 
governments any more   
Or a artificial inelegance we don't know 

we might even stand still in tech in general :)
we might even get a huge depopulation ( virus or what ever ) < if this 
happens and the virus had left problems like mass infertility reviving the 
frozen people would be top priority 

a person that's 14 < can survive in a place after being frozen for 1000 
years if humans did not evolve into a new species LOL 
they should adapt real fast
a 50 year old person will have HUGE problems ( think about your grandpa :P 
) 

we evolved more in the last 100 years then we did in the last 10.000 years 
And this is all thanx to fast communication and information exchange 

sins we had the internet we evolved even faster 

the train / motor cars / telegraph line where a slow form of the internet
The key here is 1 invention could alienate u totally
comments.author: dragnar12

comments.text:
+dragnar12 Ok, fundamental laws of the universe will probably stand, but 
our understanding of the world and the universe may change drastically or 
be at a standstill but to be honest with you it will probably be somewhere 
in the middle after all, it's just one hundred years and I know that the 
Victorian Era just under lasted one hundred years, before it we didn't even 
have mechanical spinning wheels, after that we had huge mechanical moving 
cannons (tanks), biplanes and World War I threatened to change and divide 
the world.

You could use that as an argument against me, I know you wouldn't and 
couldn't but just in case. The technological advances could be as different 
between the two events as that (It is just an opinion) but what is almost 
certain is that she would re-take school (if the difference in advances is 
substantial) to be up to date with the technological advances that has been 
accomplished since her "de-animation".

comments.text:
I went back after 30 years to visit Winnipeg last Dec/ Jan 2014.  Daytime 
highs were minus 35 C.degrees without windchill.  Holy fuck.  Coldest 
winter in 100 years.  My luck.  They say but its a dryer cold.  Ya.  It's 
like someone is shooting steel kabob skewers through your heavy clothes. 
 I'm used to a damp shivering minus 10 C.
